Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY
This award supports theoretical research and education on the effect of nonequilibrium fluctuations on nanodevices. Recent advances in technology enable the controlled fabrication of nanostructured devices. A variety of novel nanodevices utilizing mechanical, electrical, magnetic, optical and other principals have been fabricated and studied. These devices have found a broad spectrum of applications and have stimulated fundamental questions. The nanodevices are driven far from equilibrium by applied currents, optical pulses or magnetic fields. As a result, their behavior is governed by strong nonequilibrium fluctuations. The main objective of this research is to elucidate the consequences of the nonequilibrium environment in nanodevices for dynamical bistability or quantum tunneling. The PI will combine developing novel theoretical methods and their application to engineered nanodevices. Collaboration with experimental groups from University of California at Irvine and University of Minnesota will provide testing grounds for theoretical predictions.

Graduate and undergraduate students and postdocs involved in the research will learn modern computational and theoretical techniques. Collaboration with experimentalists will broaden students intellectually. Research results will be disseminated through scientific publications, conference proceedings, and presentations at national and international conferences.


TECHNICAL SUMMARY
This award supports fundamental theoretical research and education on nanodevices that operate far from the steady state of equilibrium. Advances in nanotechnology have led to the fabrication and study of a variety of mechanical, electrical, magnetic, optical and other kinds of nanodevices. Operation of these ingenious machines is often based on principles fundamentally different from macroscopic devices. In many instances they are so small that thermal and possibly quantum mechanical fluctuations of their mechanical, magnetic degrees of freedom cannot be ignored. This requires development of a probabilistic description of device operation. In particular rare but large fluctuations may completely change the operation of a device. The PI will develop a new theoretical framework to describe the behavior of nanomachines and apply it to practical nanodevices.

Graduate and undergraduate students and postdocs involved in the research will learn modern computational and theoretical techniques. Collaboration with experimentalists will broaden students intellectually. Research results will be disseminated through scientific publications, conference proceedings, and presentations at national and international conferences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Recent advances in technology allowed for a controlled fabrication of a variety of nano-magnetic and nono-mechanical devices, which found a wide spectrum of applications and pose a number of fundamental questions. The miniaturization, while being a great asset, presents a number of challenges. The largest of them is fluctuations: i.e. stochastic noises, which reduce reliability of device’s operation and make the outcome probabilistic. Such noises may originate from thermal motion, quantum uncertainty, external sources or internal material imperfections.  We have theoretically investigated the effects of such fluctuations on a variety of nano-devices: spin-torque switches, single-molecule magnets, Majorana wires (deemed to be building blocks of future quantum computers), quantum dots and cold atoms setups. In each case we developed mathematical tools, which lead to concrete recipes to optimize device performance and design further experiments to nail down the sources and consequences of the fluctuation phenomena.

Probably the most significant theoretical result of the project has to do with the Majorana wires, which utilize topologically non-trivial electronic structure of certain semiconductors brought in contact to a superconductor. We have shown that the transport in these devices has a character of an ultraslow anomalous diffusion (known to mathematicians in a very different context as the so-called Sinai diffusion).  We have proposed specific experimental setups, which will probe this prediction and allow for much better understanding and characterization of the topological quantum devices. 

A post-doctoral fellow and four graduate students were involved in the project. Two of these students has completed their Ph.D. in process of these work. One of them has joined the research branch of Seagate Technology – the leading manufacturer of hard drives, where he implements the ideas of device optimization in commercial setting. The other graduate has received a post-doctoral appointment in one of the European institutions. Results and ideas, obtained during the work on the project, were widely disseminated through publications in leading physics journals, presentations on national and international conferences and lectures on a number of summer schools.
